title: Hanging Judge: Only the ref can make a decision, not the VAR
text:
Sport Hanging Judge: Only the ref can make a decision, not the VAR

There are two words or abbreviations doing the rounds in Europe. To my knowledge, they are not even in the Oxford English Dictionary, yet they are on everyone’s lips day in, day out.

I’m sure you’ve guessed by now. Brexit and VAR (video assistant referee). Brexit doesn’t really concern us for this column. But the VAR certainly does.

As you all know by now, VAR was brought in a short time ago to try to ensure that the game was played to the letter and that justice was not only done, but seen to be done.

The doubters at the time would appear to be vindicated by the amount of discussion on its use and, in some instances, their downright opposition to it.

We first had goal line technology. That seemed to go quite well. The referee wore a gadget similar to a wristwatch that indicated to him within seconds whether the whole ball had crossed the goal line or not. Okay, so far so good.

Then along came the VAR, and it has caused nothing but trouble since its inception.

There are only four instances at the moment when the VAR will be used when there is a “clear and obvious error” or “serious missed incident” in relation to:

Goal/no goal;

Penalty/no penalty;

Direct red card (not second yellow card/caution); and

Mistaken identity (when the referee cautions or sends off the wrong player of the offending team).

It’s important to understand from the outset that only the referee can initiate a “review”; the VAR (and other match officials) can only recommend a “review” to the referee.

The final decision is always made by the referee, either based on information from the VAR or after the referee has undertaken an “on-field review”.

The protocols state quite clearly that, during the review process or when the final decision is made, players and team officials must not surround or attempt to influence the referee when the decision is reviewed.

Now, my main reason for concentrating this week on the VAR is because there have been so many inconsistencies in the Premier League of late.

Just last weekend, two such incidents came very much tothe fore.

In the Manchester United versus Liverpool game, Sadio Mané thought he’d got the first goal for Liverpool, but it was ruled out as a hand ball.

In this situation (and this is the new interpretation), the ball brushed against Mané’s hand – remember, he did not influence the flight of the ball by his action – which was reviewed and the goal was disallowed.

This was the correct decision by referee Martin Atkinson.

In the second incident, Dele Alli of Tottenham Hotspur clearly used the top part of his arm (near the shoulder) to guide the ball down to his foot, from which he scored against Watford. In this instance, the referee didn’t even consult the VAR monitor.

In my opinion, this was a clear and obvious error on the part of the referee. The goal was allowed to stand.

The main issue appears to be inconsistency among the referees, and this can only lead to debate and even confrontation that isunnecessary.

I’ve heard it said many times that all that is required is consistency. It seems as if the only thing that is consistent at the moment is the inconsistency of match officials.

Please feel free to make comments or ask questions.

Happy whistling!
